head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Prison Disturbance

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Prison Disturbance

body.head.byline: By Steve Strunsky (NYT) (Compiled by Yilu Zhao)

abstract.p: Twenty-one correction officers and three prisoners are treated for minor injuries after disturbance at Rikers Island; photo (S)

block.p: Twenty-one correction officers and three prisoners were treated for minor injuries after a disturbance at Rikers Island late Tuesday, when about 20 prisoners in a common area refused to go back to their cells, the City Department of Correction said yesterday. The officers, including three captains, were treated for exposure to a chemical spray used around 11 p.m. to subdue the prisoners, said Sandra Lewis Smith, a deputy correction commissioner. She said that the prisoners' injuries were unrelated to the spray and that the incident lasted only a few minutes. Robert Gangi, executive director of the Corrections Association of New York, a prisoners' rights group, said the spray, known as C4, should be used only as a last resort. Inmates have died from it, he said.
